Heat-resistant bricks, blocks, or tiles with a very high silica content (at least 93%). Used in high-temperature industrial applications like glass and coke ovens.
Heat-resistant ceramic bricks or blocks with 7% to 45% alumina content and over 50% combined with silica. Often used in furnaces and kilns.
Various heat-resistant ceramic bricks or blocks containing over 50% alumina, silica, or a mixture. This is a catch-all category for specific compositions not covered elsewhere.
Heat-resistant ceramic bricks, blocks, and tiles not primarily made of magnesium, calcium, chromium, alumina, or silica compounds.
Heat-resistant ceramic items like crucibles, nozzles, and pipes containing over 50% carbon. Used in metal casting and high-temperature chemical processes.
Heat-resistant ceramic items like crucibles, tubes, and rods containing over 50% alumina or an alumina-silica mix.
Heat-resistant ceramic items (not bricks) with less than 45% alumina and over 50% silica. Includes things like crucibles, tubes, and nozzles.
Heat-resistant ceramic items (not bricks) with 45% or more alumina and over 50% of silica. Used for demanding high-temperature applications.
A catch-all for various heat-resistant ceramic items like crucibles, nozzles, and tubes not covered by more specific categories (e.g., not high in carbon, alumina, or silica).
Heat-resistant ceramic items like crucibles and nozzles containing between 25% and 50% carbon.
A residual category for heat-resistant ceramic items not classified elsewhere, such as certain crucibles, tubes, or nozzles.
Standard ceramic bricks used for constructing walls and buildings.
Ceramic blocks and tiles used for flooring systems, including support or filler blocks.
Ceramic tiles designed for covering roofs to provide protection from weather.
Various ceramic construction items like chimney pots, cowls, flue liners, and architectural ornaments.
Pipes, conduits, and guttering made of ceramic, typically used for drainage and sewage systems.
Very dense ceramic tiles, like porcelain, that absorb very little water (0.5% or less). Ideal for floors and walls in wet areas like bathrooms or outdoors.
Ceramic tiles with a low to medium water absorption rate. Suitable for most indoor wall and floor applications.
More porous ceramic tiles with high water absorption (over 10%). Best used for walls in dry indoor areas.
Small ceramic tiles (mosaic cubes), often mounted on a sheet for easy installation. Used for decorative walls and floors.
Special ceramic pieces used to finish tile installations, such as border tiles, corner pieces, and decorative inserts.
Laboratory or technical equipment made from porcelain or china, such as crucibles, funnels, and evaporating dishes.
Technical ceramic articles with extreme hardness (9 or more on the Mohs scale), like alumina or silicon carbide parts. Used for wear-resistant components, seals, and cutting tools.
A range of ceramic items for technical uses not made of porcelain or extremely hard materials. Includes items like ceramic filters or substrates.
Ceramic containers like troughs and tubs for farm use, or pots and jars for transporting or packing goods.
Bathroom and sanitary fixtures like sinks, toilets, bathtubs, and bidets made from porcelain or china.
Bathroom and sanitary fixtures like sinks, toilets, and bathtubs made from ceramic materials other than porcelain, such as fireclay.
Tableware and kitchenware like plates, cups, and bowls made from porcelain or china.
Household and toilet items made of porcelain or china, excluding tableware. This includes items like vases, soap dishes, and decorative objects.
A general category for tableware, kitchenware, and other household items made from ceramics other than porcelain, such as earthenware or stoneware.
Tableware and kitchenware made from common pottery, a basic, porous type of ceramic.
Durable, non-porous tableware and kitchenware made from stoneware clay fired at a high temperature.
Tableware and kitchenware made from earthenware or fine pottery, which is often glazed. It is more porous than stoneware.
A catch-all for tableware and kitchenware made from ceramic types not listed elsewhere.
Household and toilet items (not tableware) made from basic, porous common pottery.
Durable household and toilet items (not tableware) made from non-porous stoneware.
Household and toilet items (not tableware) made from glazed earthenware or fine pottery.
A catch-all for household and toilet items made from ceramic types not listed elsewhere.
Decorative statuettes and other ornamental articles made from porcelain or china.
Decorative statuettes and other ornamental articles made from ceramic materials other than porcelain or china (e.g., earthenware, stoneware).
Decorative statuettes and other ornamental articles made from basic, common pottery.
Decorative statuettes and other ornamental articles made from earthenware or fine pottery.
A residual category for decorative statuettes and ornaments made from ceramic materials not specified elsewhere (e.g., stoneware).
A catch-all category for miscellaneous articles made of porcelain or china that are not classified elsewhere.
A catch-all category for miscellaneous articles made of ceramic materials (other than porcelain/china) that are not classified elsewhere.
Waste and scrap glass (cullet) or raw glass in large, unworked blocks or chunks.
Broken or waste glass intended for remelting and recycling.
Raw, unworked blocks of high-quality optical glass used for making lenses, prisms, and other optical components.
Raw, unworked blocks of glass, not intended for optical use.
Unworked glass in the shape of balls (not including tiny microspheres or toy balls).
Unworked rods of glass.
Unworked rods of high-quality optical glass.
Unworked rods of glass, not for optical use.
Unworked tubes made of fused quartz or other fused silica, known for high thermal and chemical resistance.
Unworked glass tubes that resist expansion when heated (low coefficient of expansion), such as borosilicate glass.
Unworked tubes of ordinary glass (not low-expansion or fused quartz).
Sheets of cast or rolled glass that are colored, coated, or opacified, but not wired or further processed.
Sheets of cast or rolled optical glass that are colored or coated.
Sheets of cast or rolled glass with an anti-reflective coating.
Sheets of cast or rolled glass that are colored, opaque, or have a reflective/absorbent layer.
Plain, unworked sheets of cast or rolled glass without any color or coating.
Plain, unworked sheets of cast or rolled optical glass.
Plain, unworked sheets of cast or rolled glass, not for optical use.
Sheets of cast or rolled glass with wire mesh embedded inside for safety and security.
Unworked glass profiles, such as U-shaped channels, used in construction.
Sheets of drawn or blown glass that are colored, coated, or opacified.
Sheets of drawn or blown optical glass that are colored or coated.
Sheets of drawn or blown glass with an anti-reflective coating.
Sheets of drawn or blown glass that are colored, opaque, or have a reflective/absorbent layer.
Plain, unworked sheets of drawn or blown glass without color or coating.
Plain, unworked sheets of drawn or blown optical glass.
Plain, unworked sheets of drawn or blown glass, not for optical use.
Sheets of high-quality float glass with a coating to absorb or reflect light, or to reduce reflection.
Sheets of high-quality float glass with an anti-reflective coating.
Thin sheets (up to 3.5mm) of high-quality float glass with a coating to absorb or reflect light.
Medium-thickness sheets (3.5mm to 4.5mm) of high-quality float glass with a coating to absorb or reflect light.
Thick sheets (over 4.5mm) of high-quality float glass with a coating to absorb or reflect light.
Sheets of high-quality float glass that are colored throughout (body-tinted) or have a ground surface.
Thin sheets (up to 3.5mm) of high-quality float glass that are colored throughout (body-tinted) or have a ground surface.
Medium-thickness sheets (3.5mm to 4.5mm) of high-quality float glass that are colored throughout (body-tinted) or have a ground surface.
Thick sheets (over 4.5mm) of high-quality float glass that are colored throughout (body-tinted) or have a ground surface.
Plain, clear, unworked sheets of high-quality float glass.
Thin sheets (up to 3.5mm) of plain, clear, unworked float glass.
Medium-thickness sheets (3.5mm to 4.5mm) of plain, clear, unworked float glass.
Thick sheets (over 4.5mm) of plain, clear, unworked float glass.
Sheets of float glass with wire mesh embedded inside for safety and security.
Glass sheets or profiles that have been processed (e.g., bent, edge-worked, engraved, enameled) but are not framed.
Optical glass sheets or profiles that have been processed (e.g., bent, edge-worked, drilled).
Non-optical glass sheets or profiles that have been processed (e.g., bent, edge-worked, engraved).
Toughened (tempered) safety glass specifically sized and shaped for use in vehicles, aircraft, or ships.
Toughened (tempered) safety glass specifically sized and shaped for use in motor vehicles.
Toughened (tempered) safety glass for aircraft, spacecraft, ships, and other vehicles (not cars).
General purpose toughened (tempered) safety glass, not for vehicles.
Toughened (tempered) safety glass that has been enameled with a colored ceramic frit.
Toughened (tempered) safety glass that is colored, coated, or opaque.
Clear, plain toughened (tempered) safety glass.
Laminated safety glass sized and shaped for use in vehicles, aircraft, or ships.
Laminated safety glass specifically sized and shaped for use in motor vehicles, such as windscreens.
Thick aluminum alloy sheets greater than 0.2mm, specifically for making beverage can lids and pull tabs.
A lightweight construction panel made of two aluminum alloy sheets bonded to a non-aluminum core, thicker than 0.2mm.
Square or rectangular aluminum alloy sheets, plates, or strips thicker than 0.2mm that are painted, varnished, or plastic-coated. Excludes specific types for beverage cans or composite panels.
Square or rectangular aluminum alloy sheets, plates, or strips with a thickness between 0.2mm and 3mm. This category excludes items that are painted, coated, or for beverage cans.
Square or rectangular aluminum alloy sheets, plates, or strips with a thickness between 3mm and 6mm. Excludes painted, varnished, or plastic-coated versions.
Thick, square or rectangular aluminum alloy sheets, plates, or strips equal to or greater than 6mm in thickness. Excludes painted, varnished, or plastic-coated versions.
Sheets, plates, and strips of pure (non-alloy) aluminum, thicker than 0.2mm, in shapes other than square or rectangular.
Sheets, plates, and strips of aluminum alloy, thicker than 0.2mm, in shapes other than square or rectangular.
Thin, unbacked aluminum foil, less than or equal to 0.2mm thick, that has been rolled but has no other processing.
Very thin household aluminum foil (less than 0.021mm thick) sold in small rolls weighing 10kg or less.
Very thin aluminum foil (less than 0.021mm thick) for industrial or bulk use, sold in rolls heavier than 10kg.
Unbacked aluminum foil with a thickness between 0.021mm and 0.2mm, rolled but not further processed.
Unbacked aluminum foil, up to 0.2mm thick, that has been rolled and then further processed (e.g., embossed, coated, printed).
Very thin aluminum foil (less than 0.021mm thick) that has been rolled and then further processed, such as by embossing or coating.
Aluminum foil with a thickness between 0.021mm and 0.2mm that has been rolled and then further processed (e.g., embossed, coated).
Aluminum foil up to 0.2mm thick that is backed with another material, such as paper or plastic.
Very thin aluminum foil (less than 0.021mm thick) that is backed with another material like paper or plastic.
A lightweight construction panel made of two aluminum sheets bonded to a non-aluminum core, with a total thickness of 0.2mm or less.
Backed aluminum foil with a thickness between 0.021mm and 0.2mm. Excludes composite panels and specialty foils.
Pipes and tubes made from pure (non-alloyed) aluminum.
Pipes and tubes made from aluminum alloys.
Pipes and tubes made from aluminum alloys that have been joined by welding.
Pipes and tubes made from aluminum alloys that have been shaped by extrusion but have not undergone further manufacturing.
Pipes and tubes made from aluminum alloys that have been processed beyond simple extrusion (e.g., drawn, threaded, polished).
Fittings for connecting aluminum tubes and pipes, such as couplings, elbows, and sleeves.
Aluminum doors, windows, their frames, and thresholds for doorways.
Miscellaneous aluminum structures and parts for construction, including specially prepared plates, rods, and tubes.
Large aluminum structures such as bridges, bridge sections, towers, and lattice masts.
Miscellaneous aluminum structures and parts for construction not covered elsewhere, like prepared rods, profiles, and tubes.
Large aluminum containers like reservoirs, tanks, and vats with a capacity over 300 liters, for holding materials other than compressed gas.
Squeezable, collapsible aluminum tubes, often used for pastes, creams, or adhesives.
Various aluminum containers like casks, drums, cans, and boxes with a capacity of 300 liters or less.
Aluminum cans specifically designed for use as aerosol spray containers.
Lightweight aluminum containers like boxes or cans made from thin foil (0.2mm or less).
General-purpose rigid aluminum containers up to 300 liters, such as drums, cans, and boxes, not covered by more specific categories.
Aluminum containers specifically designed to hold compressed or liquefied gas.
Electrical cables or wires made of aluminum strands with a reinforcing steel core.
Stranded wires, cables, and ropes made purely of aluminum (without a steel core).
Household items for kitchen or table use made of aluminum, including scouring pads.
Household kitchen or table items made from cast aluminum, such as heavy-duty pots or pans.
Household kitchen or table items made from thin aluminum foil (0.2mm or less), such as disposable baking trays.
General household kitchen or table items made from uncast aluminum (not from foil or casting), like stamped or spun pots and pans.
Sanitary items and their parts made of aluminum, such as soap dishes, toilet roll holders, or shower caddies.
A collection of aluminum fasteners including nails, tacks, staples, screws, bolts, nuts, rivets, and washers.
Woven or meshed material made from aluminum wire, such as insect screens or fencing.
Any other articles made of aluminum not specified elsewhere.
Any other articles made from cast aluminum that are not specified elsewhere.
Any other articles made from uncast aluminum (e.g., forged, stamped) that are not specified elsewhere.
Raw, purified lead in its basic, unwrought form, such as ingots or blocks.
Raw, unwrought lead where antimony is the main alloying element, making it harder.
Raw, unwrought lead that is not fully refined and does not have antimony as its main alloying element.
Unwrought lead known as 'bullion lead', which contains at least 0.02% silver and is intended for refining to extract the silver.
Raw, unwrought lead not covered by other specific categories (e.g., not refined, not high in antimony, not bullion lead).
Waste and scrap material from used lead products, intended for recycling.
Very thin lead sheets, strips, and foil with a thickness of 0.2mm or less.
Lead plates, sheets, and strips with a thickness greater than 0.2mm.
Fine particles of lead, in the form of powders or flakes.
Any other articles made of lead not specified elsewhere.
Specialized containers with a lead lining for safely transporting or storing radioactive materials.
Any other articles made of lead not specified elsewhere (e.g., weights, seals, ammunition).
Extremely pure, raw, unalloyed zinc, with a purity of 99.99% or more.
Raw, unalloyed zinc with a purity of less than 99.99%.
Raw, unalloyed zinc with a purity between 99.95% and 99.99%.
Raw, unalloyed zinc with a purity between 98.5% and 99.95%.
Raw, unalloyed zinc with a purity between 97.5% and 98.95%.
Raw, unwrought zinc that has been mixed with other elements to form an alloy.
Waste and scrap material from used zinc products, intended for recycling.

Fine particles of zinc, in the form of powders and flakes, excluding the finest 'zinc dust'.
Solid zinc in the form of bars, rods, profiles (shapes), and wire.
Flat-rolled zinc products, including plates, sheets, strips, and foil.
Any other articles made of zinc not specified elsewhere.
Raw, pure tin that has not been alloyed with other metals, usually in ingot or bar form.
Raw, unwrought tin that has been mixed with other elements to form an alloy.
Waste and scrap material from used tin products, intended for recycling.
Solid tin in the form of bars, rods, profiles (shapes), and wire.
Any other articles made of tin not specified elsewhere.
Flat-rolled tin products, including plates, sheets, and strips with a thickness greater than 0.2mm.
Any other articles made of tin not specified elsewhere (e.g., pewterware, organ pipes, decorative items).
Fine powder made from the metal tungsten.
Raw, unprocessed tungsten, including bars and rods made by sintering (heating powder without melting).
Wire made from the metal tungsten.
Waste and scrap material from used tungsten products, intended for recycling.
Any other articles made of tungsten not specified elsewhere.
Tungsten in the form of bars, rods, profiles, plates, sheets, strips, and foil.
Any other articles made of tungsten not specified elsewhere, such as filaments or electrodes.
Fine powder made from the metal molybdenum.
Raw, unprocessed molybdenum, including bars and rods made by sintering.
Molybdenum in the form of bars, rods, profiles, plates, sheets, strips, and foil.
Wire made from the metal molybdenum.
Waste and scrap material from used molybdenum products, intended for recycling.
Any other articles made of molybdenum not specified elsewhere.
Raw, unprocessed tantalum, including powders, and bars/rods made by sintering.
Waste and scrap material from used tantalum products, intended for recycling.
Crucibles (containers for high-temperature chemical reactions) made of tantalum.
Any other articles made of tantalum not specified elsewhere.
Tantalum in the form of bars, rods, profiles, wire, plates, sheets, strips, and foil.
Any other articles made of tantalum not specified elsewhere, such as parts for electronics or medical devices.
Raw, unwrought magnesium with a very high purity of 99.8% or more.
Raw, unwrought magnesium with a purity of less than 99.8%.
Scrap metal and waste from magnesium products. This does not include ash, residues, or small, graded particles like shavings or granules.
Small, graded particles of magnesium, such as shavings, filings, and granules, as well as magnesium in powder form.

Finished products made of high-purity bismuth (over 99.99% by weight) that are not specified elsewhere.
Bismuth (99.99% or less by weight) and products made from it, including waste and scrap. Excludes ash and residues.

Finished products made of bismuth (99.99% or less by weight) that are not specified elsewhere.

Titanium bars, rods, profiles (shaped sections), and wire that are not specified elsewhere.
